column2: it's far from ""luxury"". Our biggest challenge was with the bed. The bed is not at all comfortable. It's one of those Scandinavian designs with the slats underneath supporting a very
column3: very thin mattress. The slats kept falling out from the railing
column4: causing the super-thin mattress to sag. The pillows were equally bad
column5: giving no head support. All of the furniture in this place follows this trend: uncomfortable and cheap.

column1: A powerful aroma not unlike cologne dominates the lobby area. In the apartment itself
column2: two ""fragrance balls"" located at the front door fills the apartment with a strong perfume smell. If you're smell-sensitive
column3: you may want to put these balls in a plastic bag
column4: which we did. There is a large TV in the apartment
column5: and an internet connection
column6: but nothing else. We were unable to figure out how to watch anything. Although you can navigate on the TV (using the remote) to the Internet
column7: there is no keyboard on the remote so you can't log in to your favorite service. Nor could we figure out how to stream from our computers to the big screen. We felt this lack of usability was a major tease.

column7: we will not be staying here again

There is one queen sized bed in the private room and the other half of our quartet stayed in the basement where there is a full sized bed and futon available.  The house has lots of plants (both the front yard and integrated into the living space directly) and the fresh eggs directly from the hens was a novelty. We would usually go out early and return late so we didn't get to see much of Tiberio but he made us these amazing chocolate-covered cherries and a saffron cheese custard
